Description: Body sherd (mended from several fragments) of East Greek, possibly Chian, Wild Goat Style pottery dinos stand; white slip; exterior: from top, two added red bands; outlined tongue pattern; frieze of downward rays between red bands; animal frieze, one goat grazing to right (part of head and legs missing) preserved
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The findspot is uncertain as the piece does not appear on the list of objects sent by the EEF.
To date, this would be the only Chian Wild goat Style dinos stand found at the site, Robinson describes the sherd as belonging to the neck of a vase.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 101, no. 305.7, pl. XXXII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0042) (phase 2)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 211-2, no. 16)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.6069 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
